1em!important;width:auto!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk button:hover{background-color:#fff!important;border-color:#eb6500!important;color:#2e2e2e!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. For any questions on your own submission or other questions related to publishing an article, <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://service.elsevier.com/app/phone/supporthub/publishing\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">contact our Researcher support team.</span></span></a></p></div>","title":"What do these dates mean?"}},"glossary":{},"issueNavigation":{"previous":{},"next":{}},"linkingHubLinks":{},"metrics":{"metricGroup":{"citations":[],"captures":[],"mentions":[],"socialMedia":[]},"isLoading":false,"error":false,"hasMetrics":false},"preview":{},"rawtext":"","recommendations":{},"references":{},"referenceLinks":{"internal":[],"internalLoaded":false,"external":[]},"refersTo":{},"referredToBy":{},"relatedContent":{"isModal":false,"isOpenSpecialIssueArticles":false,"isOpenVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false,"isOpenRecommendations":true,"isOpenSubstances":true,"citingArticles":[false,false,false,false,false,false],"recommendations":[false,false,false,false,false,false]},"seamlessAccess":{},"specialIssueArticles":{},"substances":{},"supplementaryFilesData":[],"tableOfContents":{"showEntitledTocLinks":true},"tail":{},"transientError":{"isOpen":false},"sidePanel":{"openState":1},"viewConfig":{"articleFeature":{"aiNavigation":true},"pathPrefix":""},"virtualSpecialIssue":{"showVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false},"usageProps":{"itemStage":"S300","isAip":false,"tombAip":"0","sample":false},"userCookiePreferences":{"STRICTLY_NECESSARY":true,"PERFORMANCE":true,"FUNCTIONAL":true,"TARGETING":false}};

70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2021.10.007" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2021.10.007</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0021979721016738&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is prepared by a simple high temperature solid-state method.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping can propel kinetics behavior and boost electronic conductivity.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents a superior rate and excellent cyclic performance.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><span>In-situ XRD reveals that the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits a highly reversible phase transition process.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab015" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Sodium vanadium phosphate [Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>] with high voltage platform, low cost and environment friendliness has been considered as one of the most promising candidates as cathodes for high-performance sodium-ion batteries. However, the sodium storage property of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is limited because of its low electronic conductivity and poor kinetic performance. Herein, MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped Na<sub>(3+2x)</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>(3-x)</sub>MoO<sub>4(x)</sub> [NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x), x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15] have been developed and prepared by a feasible solid-state reaction. The optimal NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) delivers a high initial capacity of 108.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and presents an excellent capacity retention of 91.5% at 1 C after 150 cycles. In addition, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) shows a good rate capability, delivering a relatively high capacity of 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 50 C. The results of sodium storage measurement and density of states calculation indicate that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping can significantly enhance the structural stability, promote the kinetics behavior and boost the electronic conductivity of the materials. In-situ XRD test reveals that the electrochemical reaction of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits a highly reversible phase transition process. This work provides a new insight for the design of advanced cathodes for high-performance sodium-ion batteries by the strategy of unique anion doping.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005">A simple high-temperature solid state process is developed to prepare MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span><span> (x), x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15) with excellent rate capability and long cycling stability. In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> measurement reveals that the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits a highly reversible phase transition process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0045"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (212KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (212KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979721013059"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979721016751"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Sodium vanadium phosphate</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Electrochemical performance</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>In-situ XRD</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">With the successful commercialization of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), green transportation and portable electronic devices are gradually increasing in daily life <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>. However, lithium resources are faced with the bottlenecks of high cost, less reserves and uneven distribution, which hinder their larger-scale application in the future <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a><span>. <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about Sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium</a> and lithium belong to the same main group, which have similar chemical and physical properties. Therefore, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are one of the best alternatives to LIBs due to abundant and inexpensive sodium resources </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>. Nevertheless, the ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup> is larger than that of Li<sup>+</sup><span>, leading to a sluggish reaction kinetics behavior in <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> process </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. Besides, the large radius of Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> makes <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> more prone to volume expansion and structural collapse in sodium </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a>, which greatly restricts the rate capability and cycling stability of SIBs </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>In recent years, the development of advanced cathode materials with high electronic conductivity and excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a><span> for high-performance SIBs has gained considerable attention, such as layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> [Na</span></span><sub>x</sub>MO<sub>2</sub> (M&nbsp;=&nbsp;Co, Ni, Mn, etc.) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, Prussian blue analogues Na<sub>x</sub>M’<sub>y</sub>[M”(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>z</sub>·nH<sub>2</sub>O [M’(M”)&nbsp;=&nbsp;Fe, Cu, Mn, etc.] <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, and polyanionic compounds [Na<sub>3</sub>M<sub>x</sub>(XO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (M&nbsp;=&nbsp;Mn, Fe, Co, V, etc.) (X&nbsp;=&nbsp;B, P, Si, Mo, etc.)] <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>. Among the above candidates, Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) is particularly prospective and has been extensively investigated due to its typical NASCION structure, low cost and fast charge/discharge capability. In addition, NVP exhibits a high voltage platform (∼3.4&nbsp;V) with a theoretical specific capacity of 117.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. Nevertheless, the rate capability and cycling stability of NVP are greatly hampered by the intrinsic low electronic conductivity of the materials and large radius of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a><span>. The modification strategies of carbon coating and ion doping (metal ions or anions) have been generally used to improve the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span> of NVP. Carbon coating can effectively enhance the surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> of the materials </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>. For ion doping, the partial substitution at sodium and/or vanadium sites can improve the electronic conductivity of NVP and thus promote the electrochemical performance of the materials. Most of investigations on NVP materials with metal ion doping focus on the substitution of Na and/or vanadium sites, such as Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>(2-x)</sub>Mg<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>(2-x)</sub>Cr<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>(3-x)</sub>K<sub>x</sub>V<sub>(2-y)</sub>Mg<sub>y</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, and so on.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">So far, to our knowledge, there are few reports for nonmetal substitution of NVP at the inactive anion (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup>) sites, except for some cases on Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>P<sub>3–x</sub>B<sub>x</sub>O<sub>12</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, and Na<sub>3+x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3−x</sub>(SiO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>x</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. However, these few investigations have proved that the partial replacements at the inactive anion (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup>) sites can modulate and boost the electrochemical characteristics of the materials without the reduction, even promote theoretical capacity of the materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a><span>. At present, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/anionic-group" title="Learn more about anionic groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anionic groups</a> of BO</span><sub>3</sub><sup>3−</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, and SiO<sub>4</sub><sup>4−</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a> have been utilized to replace PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup> in NVP materials. It is noted that the ionic structure of BO<sub>3</sub><sup>3−</sup> is triangle, while the other two are tetrahedron, meaning that the replacement of isostructural SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> or SiO<sub>4</sub><sup>4−</sup> for PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup> may be more superior than BO<sub>3</sub><sup>3−</sup> owing to the structural similarity. In fact, SiO<sub>4</sub><sup>4−</sup> or SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> modified NVP materials do exhibit better <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> than BO</span><sub>3</sub><sup>3−</sup>-doped NVP <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. On the other hand, MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> is tetrahedral, which is similar to PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup>. Therefore, it can be reasonably anticipated that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> may partially replace PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup> at PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup> site to adjust the crystal structure of NVP and improve its sodium storage performance. To our knowledge, there are no reports on MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Herein, MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP materials have been developed by the partial substitution of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> for PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup> and utilized as advanced cathodes for SIBs. A series of Na<sub>(3+2x)</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>(3-x)</sub>MoO<sub>4(x)</sub> [NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x), x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15] samples have been prepared by a simple high-temperature solid-state reaction. The MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP with enhanced electronic conductivity can facilitate Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion and raise the sodium storage performance. As a result, the as-prepared NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits superior electrochemical performance, delivering the awesome initial specific capacity of 108.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (1 C) and relatively high capacity of 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at an ultrahigh rate of 50 C, and exhibiting excellent cycling stability even at 30 C for 2000 cycles.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045">A simple high-temperature solid-state reaction was employed to synthesize Na<sub>(3+2x)</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>(3-x)</sub>MoO<sub>4(x)</sub> [NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x), x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15]. To investigate the effect of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping on the electrochemical performance of the NVP, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) with various doping amounts were prepared in this work (more details of synthetic procedure can be found in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a presents the crystal structure of the NVP with the <em>R</em>-3<em>c</em> space group and depicts the graphical representation of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping in the lattices of the NVP. The open three-dimensional structure and components of the NVP are well matched. [VO<sub>6</sub><span>] <a href="/topics/chemistry/octahedral-crystal" title="Learn more about octahedron from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">octahedron</a> and [PO</span><sub>4</sub>] tetrahedron form a basic unit of V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> via sharing oxygen atoms, as exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>a. And each unit can generate a large number of internal gaps, which facilitates the storage of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. Because of the difference in the oxygen environments, there are two different kinds of Na<sup>+</sup> (Na1, Na2) in the lattice, and the electrochemical activity of Na2 is higher than that of Na1 owing to the much weaker bonding of Na2 than Na1 <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1.jpg" height="491" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (499KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (499KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span>(a) Crystal structure of NVP. (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (x). (c) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b displays the XRD patterns of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10 and 0.15). All NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (x) present sharp and similar diffraction peaks, which can be indexed to a typical <a href="/topics/chemistry/nasicons" title="Learn more about NASICON from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NASICON</a> (JCPDS No.53–0018) structure with </span><em>R</em>-3<em>c</em> space group. Obviously, the crystal structure of the NVP maintains well after MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a><span> exhibits the <a href="/topics/materials-science/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinements</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) based on the XRD data in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b, while the corresponding crystal cell parameters and refinement factors are listed in Table S1. According to the refinements results, the refinement factors of χ<sup>2</sup>, Rwp and Rp are not more than 3.045, 7.52% and 5.81%, respectively, indicating that the observed results are in good agreement with the calculated patterns. Tables S2 and S3 display the crystallographic data of the NVP and the proportion of P in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10), respectively. With the increase of the doping amount of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span>, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> a and c of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) change slightly, which means that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> has successfully entered into the lattices of the NVP.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span>The <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of the as-prepared NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) is exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c. There are two characteristic peaks in the range of 1100–2000&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>. The signal peak sited at 1357&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is ascribed to D band, while the another signal situated at 1598&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is assigned to G band of carbon <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>. The intensity ratios of D-band and G-band (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span><span>) can indicate the <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon materials</a>. The ratios of I</span><sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> are 1.01, 1.02, 1.01 and 1.06 for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15), respectively. All the ratios of I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> are all greater than 1, demonstrating the presence of disorder carbon in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x), which is beneficial to enhance the electronic conductivity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. Moreover, the resistivity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) is collected by four-probe test, and the results are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>. It can be observed that the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(0.10) (14.09&nbsp;Ω/cm) presents the optimal electronic conductivity, which is superior to the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) (19.45&nbsp;Ω/cm), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (16.44&nbsp;Ω/cm) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (31.74&nbsp;Ω/cm).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a-2d exhibit the SEM images of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) presents irregular morphology with an average size of 100–200&nbsp;nm. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b-2d, the particle sizes of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) slightly increase after the doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. The TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e-2f. The distinct lattice finger (0.283&nbsp;nm) is observed, corresponding to the (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) crystal plane of the material. Moreover, the surface of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) is covered with an <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a> layer (∼0.846&nbsp;nm). This carbon layer may boost the electron conductivity of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) and thus improve electrochemical performance. The results of HRTEM and SEAD indicate that the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) material presents good crystal characteristics. The element mapping images exhibit that the elements of sodium (Na), phosphorus (P), vanadium (V), molybdenum (Mo), carbon (C), and oxygen (O) are homogeneously distributed in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 2</span></span></a>g and S3).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2.jpg" height="432" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (737KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (737KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. SEM images of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(x) with different MoO<sub>4</sub><span> contents: (a) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, (b) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.05, (c) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.10, (d) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.15. (e) <a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about TEM images from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM images</a>, (f) HRTEM images and (g) element mapping of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) sample.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">XPS measurement is employed to confirm surface chemical constituents and bonds of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). The XPS survey spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>) indicates the existence of Na, P, V, Mo, C and O, which is in accord with the element mapping of the material (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g). In the C 1s spectra, the signal peak situated at 284.8&nbsp;eV is attributed to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond, while the other peaks located at 285.8 and 289.0&nbsp;eV are assigned to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bonds, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. The O 1s spectra is observed and can be fitted into four peaks, of which two peaks situated at 531.43 and 532.37&nbsp;eV are attributed to O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">P and O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>C and another two characteristic peaks at 533.03 and 534.43&nbsp;eV are ascribed to <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxygen-vacancy" title="Learn more about oxygen vacancies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen vacancies</a> and adsorbed H</span><sub>2</sub>O, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. The V 2p spectra exhibits two signal peaks at 516.35 and 523.26&nbsp;eV, which can be assigned to the signals of V 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and V 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c). It is shown that the V of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) mainly exists in the form of trivalence <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/x-ray-photoelectron-spectrum" title="Learn more about XPS spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS spectrum</a> of Mo 3d in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d displays two peaks (228.69 and 231.85&nbsp;eV), corresponding to Mo 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and Mo 3d<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, illustrating the presence of Mo<sup>4+</sup> in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). In addition, the other characteristic peaks at 229.32, 232.99 and 236.00&nbsp;eV are assigned to Mo 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and Mo 3d<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, illustrating the presence of Mo<sup>5+</sup> and Mo<sup>6+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a><span>. Clearly, Mo element exists in the form of <a href="/topics/chemistry/mixed-valence" title="Learn more about mixed valence from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mixed valence</a> states.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3.jpg" height="531" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (345KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (345KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/xps-analysis" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a> for NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (0.10). (a) C 1s; (b) O 1s; (c) V 2p; (d) Mo 3d of <a href="/topics/chemistry/x-ray-photoelectron-spectrum" title="Learn more about XPS spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS spectra</a>.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> displays the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). The first charging and discharging profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (x) at a low <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 1 C (1 C&nbsp;=&nbsp;117&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>−1</sup>) under the voltage window of 2.4–4.3&nbsp;V (vs Na<sup>+</sup>/Na) are exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a. Among them, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents the highest reversible capacity of 108.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (1 C). As a contrast, the discharge specific capacities of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) in the first cycle are 94.3, 90.0 and 81.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup><span>, respectively. According to the charging and discharging profiles, the voltage platform is obvious at&nbsp;∼&nbsp;3.4&nbsp;V, which can be assigned to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of V</span><sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Obviously, the specific discharge capacity of the material can be effectively enhanced by the introduction of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b exhibits the cycling stability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). The material of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) delivers the high specific capacity of 99.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 1 C after 150 cycles and shows the good capacity retention. Nevertheless, the reversible capacities of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) are 61.1, 81.6, and 81.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C after 150 cycles, respectively. The charge/discharge curves of the first five cycles for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at 1 C are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c. They almost completely overlap, indicating excellent cycling stability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4.jpg" height="670" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (610KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (610KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) First charging and discharging profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) at 1 C. (b) Cyclic stability of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) for 150 cycles. (c) Charge-discharge curves of the first five cycles of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). (d) Rate capability of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped samples at different rates. (e) and (f) Charging and discharging profiles of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) at different rates.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>d and S5 exhibit the rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). Clearly, the rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) have been greatly enhanced after MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits the optimal rate capability. Along with the increase of current density from 0.5 to 20 C for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10), the discharge capacity remains almost constant, while the specific discharge capacity is mildly decreases to 92 (20 C) and 90.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (30 C). Amazingly, the discharge capacity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is up to 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> even at a superhigh current density of 50 C, while the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) present much lower capacities of 74 and 53.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 50 C, respectively. Moreover, when the current density is adjusted back to 0.5 C, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) can even return to the initial state, indicating the excellent rate capability. However, the capacity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) decays to 46&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (10 C) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>e, 4f and S5 exhibit the charge/discharge profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) at different current densities. Compared with the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the charging and discharging curves of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.05, 0.10, 0.15) present coupled steady plateaus. The voltage platform in the charging and discharging profiles do not vanish even though at 50 C, illustrating that the sodiation/desodiation processes are still in progress in MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped electrodes at high current densities. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a><span> exhibits the relationship between <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and doping amount in the materials. It can be seen that the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) displays the outstanding <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> of ∼358.2 Wh/kg (1 C), which is significantly higher than that of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0) (284.8 Wh/kg), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (297.7 Wh/kg) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (269.4 Wh/kg).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Figs. 5 and S7 exhibit long cycling stability for the as-prepared NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) materials. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents an outstanding initial capacity of 103&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 C and exhibits the retention rate of 81.6% after 500 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). Even after 1000 cycles, the average coulombic efficiency is almost close to 100%. However, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>b) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>c) present the inferior capacities of 75.9 and 78.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> under the same condition. Furthermore, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) cathode can still deliver the initial capacity of 90.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 30 C and remain at 50.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 2000 cycles, indicating splendid long cycling performance. Nevertheless, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>a) electrode gives the initial specific capacity of 85&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 5 C, and only holds the capacity of 66.5&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles. In addition, the microstructures of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) after 500 cycles at 1 C are observed by SEM (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>). Compared with the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the morphology of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) changes little even after 500 cycles. The comparison of half-cell performance between this work and the recently reported investigations for sodium-ion batteries is shown in Table S4. Obviously, the overall electrochemical performance of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(0.10), especially rate capability, is excellent among various NVP-based materials. Consequently, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) may be the promising <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> for SIBs because of its outstanding rate performance and long cyclic stability.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5.jpg" height="356" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (338KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (338KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Long cycling performance of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at the rates of 20 C (a) and 30 C (b), respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> displays the CV profiles of the NVP and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> between 2.4 and 4.3&nbsp;V. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>, the redox reactions of the NVP and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) occur at the voltage of&nbsp;∼3.4&nbsp;V, which is consistent with the extraction/insertion of Na<sup>+</sup><span> in the crystal structure of the NVP. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation process</a> is ascribed to the two-phase transition process of Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and NaV<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) displays a stronger oxidation peak than the NVP. As for the process of reduction, the peaks are divided into two parts due to the structural rearrangement when Na<sup>+</sup> transfers from the Na1 site to the Na2 site <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. The small reduction peak corresponds to the short discharge platform in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a. Moreover, the polarization voltage of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode between cathode and anode peaks is 211&nbsp;mV, which is visibly less than that of the NVP (301&nbsp;mV). Clearly, compared with the pristine NVP, MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP possesses excellent electrochemical reversibility and improved reaction kinetics.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>In order to further study the <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-kinetics-characteristics" title="Learn more about kinetic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kinetic properties</a> of the materials, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) tests are carried out. Nyquist diagram and the fitting result of EIS circuit model are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>a. The EIS spectra is composed of a semicircle and a slash in the high/low frequency regions. The semicircle is assigned to the charge transfer process, while the diagonal line is associated with the diffusion of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> (Warburg impedance) </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. Based on the calculation and fitting of equivalent circuit, the R<sub>ct</sub> of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) (252.2&nbsp;Ω) is much smaller than that of the NVP (408.3&nbsp;Ω), illustrating a faster charge transfer dynamic for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b demonstrates the linear relationship of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) materials in the Ź vs ω<sup>−1/2</sup>. As calculated, the slope of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) is higher than that of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10), indicating a lower value of <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> (<em>D<sub>Na</sub></em>). Obviously, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode presents low charge transfer resistance and fast Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics, indicating that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping can enhance rate capability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" height="230" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (174KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (174KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) EIS of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) with an equivalent circuit. (b) Relation between Ź and ω<sup>−1/2</sup> at low frequency of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0 and 0.10).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a><span> exhibits the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10). The shapes of the CV profiles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>a) at different rates (0.2–1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) are similar, and the peak current (<em>i</em>) increases with the increase of scanning rates (<em>v</em>), manifesting that there is a distinct capacitive behavior in the electrochemical process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. According to Eqs. (3) and (4) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>, the <em>b</em> values of oxidation and reduction peaks in CV profiles are 0.62 and 0.85, respectively, demonstrating that the dynamic behavior of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is controlled via both diffusion and capacitive behavior. The contribution rates of two controlled processes are obtained via formula (5) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>. The capacitive contribution is 94.14% at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>b). The proportions of capacitive/diffusion contribution at various scanning rates are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>c. When the scanning rates are 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, the contributions of capacitive behavior are 88.62, 93.37, 94.57, 94.91 and 95.37%, respectively, meaning that the outstanding rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is mainly contributed via high capacitive behaviour <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a><span><span>. Galvanostatic intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) are used to further probe the </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the corresponding results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>d-10f. It can be seen that the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> is mainly at the range of 10</span><sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>.
