Obviously, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode presents low charge transfer resistance and fast Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics, indicating that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping can enhance rate capability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" height="230" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (174KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (174KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) EIS of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) with an equivalent circuit. (b) Relation between Ź and ω<sup>−1/2</sup> at low frequency of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0 and 0.10).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a><span> exhibits the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10). The shapes of the CV profiles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>a) at different rates (0.2–1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) are similar, and the peak current (<em>i</em>) increases with the increase of scanning rates (<em>v</em>), manifesting that there is a distinct capacitive behavior in the electrochemical process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. According to Eqs. (3) and (4) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>, the <em>b</em> values of oxidation and reduction peaks in CV profiles are 0.62 and 0.85, respectively, demonstrating that the dynamic behavior of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is controlled via both diffusion and capacitive behavior. The contribution rates of two controlled processes are obtained via formula (5) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>. The capacitive contribution is 94.14% at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>b). The proportions of capacitive/diffusion contribution at various scanning rates are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>c. When the scanning rates are 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, the contributions of capacitive behavior are 88.62, 93.37, 94.57, 94.91 and 95.37%, respectively, meaning that the outstanding rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is mainly contributed via high capacitive behaviour <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a><span><span>. Galvanostatic intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) are used to further probe the </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the corresponding results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>d-10f. It can be seen that the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> is mainly at the range of 10</span><sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>. There is no doubt that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping facilitates the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup><span>, and the <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> modified NVP is higher than that of previously reported NASICON-type NVP materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The electrical effects of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> doped NVP are ascertained via the calculation of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (DOS) and the results are shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>. The crystal structures of the NVP and MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP is simulated, as displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b, the band gap of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) is 4.97&nbsp;eV. For the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) (band gap&nbsp;=&nbsp;3.67&nbsp;eV), some new energy states appear around the bottom of <a href="/topics/chemistry/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a>, significantly narrowing the width of foregoing band gap in the pristine NVP and enhancing the electronic conductivity. Further analyzing the partial DOS (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>) shows that these nascent states in the band gap above the E<sub>f</sub><span> mainly come from the contribution of <a href="/topics/chemistry/molybdenum-atom" title="Learn more about Mo atom from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Mo atom</a>. Hence, one can conclude that MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> doping could induce the change of local structure and modify the electronic structure. Thus, the appearance of new energy states may improve the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of the NVP </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7.jpg" height="491" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (558KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (558KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span>Structural diagram (a) and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (b) of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">For illustrating the structural evolution of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode during desodiation/sodiation process, in-situ XRD of the material is collected. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 8</span></span></a><span> and S12 exhibit the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about diffraction patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffraction patterns</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) at different charge states. To be specific, the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;4), (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;4), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;6) and (3&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) four profiles shift to right. At discharging, the four peaks completely return to the initial state. Moreover, the (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;3) and (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;<span>1) peaks split into new peaks and gradually disappear. During discharging, the peaks gradually appear again. The results present that all the diffraction peaks significant change and gradually return to the pristine state during charging and discharging, indicating that the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) is highly reversible.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8.jpg" height="261" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (548KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (548KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. <span>In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode during the first cycle.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">To summarize, we have synthetized Na<sub>(3+2x)</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>(3-x)</sub>MoO<sub>4(x)</sub> cathode materials as advanced cathodes for SIBs. The doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> significantly reduces the internal resistance and accelerates the migration rate of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> in the NVP-based materials, resulting in an obvious enhancement of electrochemical performance. The optimum content of MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> is 0.10. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents excellent rate capability and cycling stability, which exhibits the outstanding rate capability of 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup><span> at a superhigh <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 50 C. Moreover, the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) shows a relatively specific capacity of 73.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with an average coulombic efficiency of 99.2% even at 20 C after 1000 cycles. The EIS measurement and DOS computation demonstrate that the faster sodium ion kinetics and lower band gap after the doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> account for the excellent rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). In-situ XRD manifests that the structure of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) undergoes a highly reversible phase transition process. We believe that the anionic doping strategy not only sheds a new insight for the modification of NVP, but also provides a reference for the practical application of polyanionic SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><strong>Xiao Liu:</strong> Investigation, Methodology, Conceptualization, Writing – original draft, Software. <strong>Juan Gong:</strong> Software, Visualization, Formal analysis. <strong>Xijun Wei:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Ling Ni:</strong> Data curation, Visualization. <strong>Houyang Chen:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Qiaoji Zheng:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Chenggang Xu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Dunmin Lin:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">This work was supported by Sichuan Science and Technology Program (2018JY0447) and Project of Southwest University of Science and Technology (No. 20zx7142).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Supplementary material</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The following are the Supplementary data to this article:<span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="m0005"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" title="Download Word document (3MB)"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" width="20" class="icon icon-text-document"><path d="M1 10v108h57.22L91 85.09V10H1m80 70.96L54.07 108H11V20h70v60.96zM43 100h10V80h20V70H43v30M25 32h42v10H25V32zm0 18h42v10H25V50z"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download Word document (3MB)</span></span></span></a></span><span class="captions text-s"><span><p><span class="label">Supplementary data 1</span>. </p></span></span></span></span></div></section></div></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="bi005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" id="ref-id-b0005" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0005"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">G. Zhai, J. Qu, S.-M. Hao, Y.-Q. Jing, W. Chang, J. Wang, W. Li, Y. Abdelkrim, H. Yuan, Z.-Z. Yu</div><div id="ref-id-h0020" class="title text-m">Layered birnessite cathode with a displacement/intercalation mechanism for high-performance aqueous zinc-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host Li, R. Deng, Q. Li, D. Lin, X. Wei, X. Liu, N.a. Jiang, Y.u. Huo, F. Xie, Q. Zheng</div><div id="ref-id-h0240" class="title text-m">Metal−organic framework-derived ZnSe- and Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se-filled porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanocubes interconnected by reduced graphene oxide for sodium-ion battery anodes</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Inorg. Dou</div><div id="ref-id-h0245" class="title text-m">A cation and anion dual doping strategy for the elevation of titanium redox potential for high-power sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Angew. Liang, X. Li, F. Zhao, J. Zhang, Y. Liu, L. Hou, C. Yuan</div><div id="ref-id-h0250" class="title text-m">Construction and operating mechanism of high-rate Mo-doped Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@C nanowires toward practicable wide-temperature-tolerance Na-ion and hybrid Li/Na-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. class="reference" id="h0255"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">J. Zhang, Y. Liu, X. Zhao, L. He, H. Liu, Y. Song, S. Sun, Q. Li, X. Xing, J. Chen</div><div id="ref-id-h0255" class="title text-m">A novel NASICON-type Na<sub>4</sub>MnCr(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> demonstrating the energy density record of phosphate cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Mater., 32 (11) (2020), p. 1906348, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.v32.1110.1002/adma.201906348" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1002/adma.v32.1110.1002/adma.201906348</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85079446867&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20novel%20NASICON-type%20Na4MnCr3%20demonstrating%20the%20energy%20density%20record%20of%20phosphate%20cathodes%20for%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2020&amp;author=J.%20Zhang&amp;author=Y.%20Liu&amp;author=X.%20Zhao&amp;author=L.%20He&amp;author=H.%20Liu&amp;author=Y.%20Song&amp;author=S.%20Sun&amp;author=Q.%20Li&amp;author=X.%20Xing&amp;author=J.%20Chen" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (32)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723017502"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A high-energy-density NASICON-type Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;1.25&lt;/inf&gt;Ga&lt;inf&gt;0.75&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode with reversible V&lt;sup&gt;4+&lt;/sup&gt;/V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt; redox couple for sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">The stable three-dimensional framework and high operating voltage of sodium superionic conductor (NASICON)-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> has the potential to work with long cycle life and high-rate performance; however, it suffers from the poor intrinsic electronic conductivity and low energy density. Herein, Ga<sup>3+</sup> is introduced into Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> to activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple at a high potential of 4.0&nbsp;V for enhancing energy density of the materials (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>). After the partial substitution of Ga<sup>3+</sup> for V<sup>3+</sup>, three redox couples (V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) of V are reversibly converted in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, suggesting multi-electrons (&gt;2e<sup>−</sup>) involved in the reversible reaction, and simultaneously the electronic conductivity of the materials is effectively enhanced. As a result, the cathode with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.75 exhibits excellent electrochemical properties: in the voltage range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, delivering an initial capacity of 105 mAh/g at 1C with a capacity retention rate of 92.3% after 400 cycles, and providing a stable reversible capacity of 88.3 mAh/g at 40C; and in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, presenting the reversible capacity 152.3 mAh/g at 1C (497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>), and cycling stably for 1000 cycles at 20C with a capacity decay of 0.02375% per cycle. It is found that the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes possess the sodium storage mechanism of single-phase and bi-phase reactions. This investigation presents a useful strategy to enhance the energy density and cycling life of NASICON-structured polyanionic phosphates by activating high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1005030223004383"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Cr-doped Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;@C enables high-capacity with V&lt;sup&gt;2+&lt;/sup&gt;/V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt; reaction and stable sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Materials Science and Technology</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The NVCP@C delivers an ultrahigh discharge capacity (175 mAh g–1) and cyclability (86% capacity retention for 2000 cycles). Compared with the recently reported NASICON-type SIB electrode materials [15,18,23,30,32,36,42,45,46], this work demonstrates good capacity, cycle performance, and rate performance (Table S3). In-situ XRD results demonstrate that there are two reversible sodium storage mechanisms during charge and discharge: two-phase reactions and solid solution reactions.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Due to its abundant sodium content and low cost, sodium-ion battery (SIB) has become an effective substitute and supplement for lithium-ion batteries, which has a broad development prospect in large-scale energy storage systems. Na-super-ionic conductor (NASICON) structural materials have stable 3D skeleton structures and open Na<sup>+</sup> transport channels, which is a very promising SIB cathode material. But in the typical NASICON material Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP), the number of electrons involved in NVP per formula unit is less than 2 at the stable voltage window, which limits the further improvement of battery performance. In this work, we report another NASICON structured Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>4/3</sub>Cr<sub>2/3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@C (NVCP@C), which is obtained by Cr-doped NVP through spray drying. By taking full advantage of the voltage platforms of V<sup>5+/4+</sup>, V<sup>4+/3+</sup>, and V<sup>3+/2+</sup> in the window of 1.5–4.4&nbsp;V, NVCP@C delivered a high discharge capacity (175 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>) and durable cyclability (86% capacity retention for 2000 cycles). <em>In-situ</em> X-ray diffraction results demonstrate that the reversible structural evolution accompanies by solid-solution reaction and two-phase reaction mechanisms co-exist during charge/discharge processes. When coupled with Na<sup>+</sup> pre-embedded hard carbon (HC), the assembled NVCP@C//HC full cell delivers a high capacity (105 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>) and long cycling performance (70% after 1000 cycles). This Cr-doped NVP method offers new insights into the design of high-energy NASICON-structured cathode materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2589234723000714"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Strategies and practical approaches for stable and high energy density sodium-ion battery: a step closer to commercialization</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Materials Today Sustainability</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are reckoned as a potential alternative to Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Currently, the limited supply of precursors and the cost of LIBs have regenerated research and development interest in SIBs. Due to differences in the chemistry of lithium (Li) and sodium (Na), optimized methods for LIBs cannot be blindly applied to develop SIBs. Along with the judicial selection of electrode materials, electrolytes, and interfaces are very crucial for safe, high-power, and long-lasting batteries. The initial part of this review deals with the challenges faced in commercializing SIB full cells. Subsequently, the strategies to improve the energy density of SIB full cells through electrode modifications and electrolyte engineering are described in detail. This review comprehensively represents notable insights into the large-scale commercialization of potential sodium-ion batteries in the full cell.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0022459622007940"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">The recent advances of NASICON-Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Solid State Chemistry</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Table 5 summary of NVPF cathodes with different modification methods in recent years. The substitution of anionic functional groups [141–143] is also a hot topic of current research. The common anionic functional groups include: MoO42− [141], SiO42− [144], etc.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">NASICON (super ionic conductor)-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) has been widely studied as a very promising cathode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical specific capacity, high voltage platform, good chemical stability, its unique three-dimensional (3D) open crystal structure, and the de/intercalation of sodium ions during charge/discharge. However, the high Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion ability of NVP is accompanied by the large bulk structure and poor electronic conductivity, which leads to poor electrochemical performance in terms of rate capability and cycling stability and thus impedes its practical application. Herein, the research development of NVP sodium ion cathode materials are reviewed in recent years. Based on the crystal structure and ion migration mechanism of NVP materials, the sodium storage mechanism and theoretical capacitance of NVP materials are introduced, and the effects of different preparation methods on the electrochemical properties of NVP materials are summarized and compared. The modification research strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of NVP electrode materials are mainly discussed, including carbon material modification, ion doping, and material Nano-crystallization. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and prospects for the future development of NVP cathodes.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/smll.202304002" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">High-Energy-Density Cathode Achieved via the Activation of a Three-Electron Reaction in Sodium Manganese Vanadium Phosphate for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2023, Small</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.nanolett.2c03916" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Bimetal Substitution Enabled Energetic Polyanion Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 class="authors"><span>Xinran</span> <span>Li</span>, …, <span>Mengqiang</span> <span>Wu</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
