And each unit can generate a large number of internal gaps, which facilitates the storage of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. Because of the difference in the oxygen environments, there are two different kinds of Na<sup>+</sup> (Na1, Na2) in the lattice, and the electrochemical activity of Na2 is higher than that of Na1 owing to the much weaker bonding of Na2 than Na1 <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1.jpg" height="491" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (499KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (499KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span>(a) Crystal structure of NVP. (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (x). (c) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b displays the XRD patterns of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.05, 0.10 and 0.15). All NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (x) present sharp and similar diffraction peaks, which can be indexed to a typical <a href="/topics/chemistry/nasicons" title="Learn more about NASICON from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NASICON</a> (JCPDS No.53–0018) structure with </span><em>R</em>-3<em>c</em> space group. Obviously, the crystal structure of the NVP maintains well after MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a><span> exhibits the <a href="/topics/materials-science/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinements</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) based on the XRD data in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b, while the corresponding crystal cell parameters and refinement factors are listed in Table S1. According to the refinements results, the refinement factors of χ<sup>2</sup>, Rwp and Rp are not more than 3.045, 7.52% and 5.81%, respectively, indicating that the observed results are in good agreement with the calculated patterns. Tables S2 and S3 display the crystallographic data of the NVP and the proportion of P in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10), respectively. With the increase of the doping amount of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span>, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> a and c of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) change slightly, which means that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> has successfully entered into the lattices of the NVP.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span>The <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of the as-prepared NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (x) is exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c. There are two characteristic peaks in the range of 1100–2000&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>. The signal peak sited at 1357&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is ascribed to D band, while the another signal situated at 1598&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is assigned to G band of carbon <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>. The intensity ratios of D-band and G-band (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span><span>) can indicate the <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon materials</a>. The ratios of I</span><sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> are 1.01, 1.02, 1.01 and 1.06 for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15), respectively. All the ratios of I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> are all greater than 1, demonstrating the presence of disorder carbon in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x), which is beneficial to enhance the electronic conductivity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. Moreover, the resistivity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) is collected by four-probe test, and the results are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>. It can be observed that the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(0.10) (14.09&nbsp;Ω/cm) presents the optimal electronic conductivity, which is superior to the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) (19.45&nbsp;Ω/cm), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (16.44&nbsp;Ω/cm) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (31.74&nbsp;Ω/cm).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a-2d exhibit the SEM images of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) presents irregular morphology with an average size of 100–200&nbsp;nm. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b-2d, the particle sizes of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) slightly increase after the doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. The TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e-2f. The distinct lattice finger (0.283&nbsp;nm) is observed, corresponding to the (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) crystal plane of the material. Moreover, the surface of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) is covered with an <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a> layer (∼0.846&nbsp;nm). This carbon layer may boost the electron conductivity of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) and thus improve electrochemical performance. The results of HRTEM and SEAD indicate that the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) material presents good crystal characteristics. The element mapping images exhibit that the elements of sodium (Na), phosphorus (P), vanadium (V), molybdenum (Mo), carbon (C), and oxygen (O) are homogeneously distributed in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 2</span></span></a>g and S3).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2.jpg" height="432" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (737KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (737KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. SEM images of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(x) with different MoO<sub>4</sub><span> contents: (a) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, (b) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.05, (c) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.10, (d) x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.15. (e) <a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about TEM images from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM images</a>, (f) HRTEM images and (g) element mapping of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) sample.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">XPS measurement is employed to confirm surface chemical constituents and bonds of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). The XPS survey spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>) indicates the existence of Na, P, V, Mo, C and O, which is in accord with the element mapping of the material (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g). In the C 1s spectra, the signal peak situated at 284.8&nbsp;eV is attributed to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond, while the other peaks located at 285.8 and 289.0&nbsp;eV are assigned to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bonds, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. The O 1s spectra is observed and can be fitted into four peaks, of which two peaks situated at 531.43 and 532.37&nbsp;eV are attributed to O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">P and O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>C and another two characteristic peaks at 533.03 and 534.43&nbsp;eV are ascribed to <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxygen-vacancy" title="Learn more about oxygen vacancies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen vacancies</a> and adsorbed H</span><sub>2</sub>O, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. The V 2p spectra exhibits two signal peaks at 516.35 and 523.26&nbsp;eV, which can be assigned to the signals of V 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and V 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c). It is shown that the V of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) mainly exists in the form of trivalence <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/x-ray-photoelectron-spectrum" title="Learn more about XPS spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS spectrum</a> of Mo 3d in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d displays two peaks (228.69 and 231.85&nbsp;eV), corresponding to Mo 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and Mo 3d<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, illustrating the presence of Mo<sup>4+</sup> in the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). In addition, the other characteristic peaks at 229.32, 232.99 and 236.00&nbsp;eV are assigned to Mo 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and Mo 3d<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, illustrating the presence of Mo<sup>5+</sup> and Mo<sup>6+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a><span>. Clearly, Mo element exists in the form of <a href="/topics/chemistry/mixed-valence" title="Learn more about mixed valence from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mixed valence</a> states.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3.jpg" height="531" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (345KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (345KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/xps-analysis" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a> for NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (0.10). (a) C 1s; (b) O 1s; (c) V 2p; (d) Mo 3d of <a href="/topics/chemistry/x-ray-photoelectron-spectrum" title="Learn more about XPS spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS spectra</a>.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> displays the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). The first charging and discharging profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (x) at a low <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 1 C (1 C&nbsp;=&nbsp;117&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>−1</sup>) under the voltage window of 2.4–4.3&nbsp;V (vs Na<sup>+</sup>/Na) are exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a. Among them, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents the highest reversible capacity of 108.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (1 C). As a contrast, the discharge specific capacities of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) in the first cycle are 94.3, 90.0 and 81.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup><span>, respectively. According to the charging and discharging profiles, the voltage platform is obvious at&nbsp;∼&nbsp;3.4&nbsp;V, which can be assigned to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of V</span><sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Obviously, the specific discharge capacity of the material can be effectively enhanced by the introduction of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b exhibits the cycling stability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). The material of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) delivers the high specific capacity of 99.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 1 C after 150 cycles and shows the good capacity retention. Nevertheless, the reversible capacities of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) are 61.1, 81.6, and 81.9&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C after 150 cycles, respectively. The charge/discharge curves of the first five cycles for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at 1 C are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c. They almost completely overlap, indicating excellent cycling stability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4.jpg" height="670" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (610KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (610KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) First charging and discharging profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) at 1 C. (b) Cyclic stability of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) for 150 cycles. (c) Charge-discharge curves of the first five cycles of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). (d) Rate capability of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped samples at different rates. (e) and (f) Charging and discharging profiles of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) at different rates.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>d and S5 exhibit the rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x). Clearly, the rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) have been greatly enhanced after MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) exhibits the optimal rate capability. Along with the increase of current density from 0.5 to 20 C for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10), the discharge capacity remains almost constant, while the specific discharge capacity is mildly decreases to 92 (20 C) and 90.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (30 C). Amazingly, the discharge capacity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is up to 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> even at a superhigh current density of 50 C, while the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) present much lower capacities of 74 and 53.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 50 C, respectively. Moreover, when the current density is adjusted back to 0.5 C, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) can even return to the initial state, indicating the excellent rate capability. However, the capacity of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) decays to 46&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> (10 C) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>e, 4f and S5 exhibit the charge/discharge profiles of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) at different current densities. Compared with the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the charging and discharging curves of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.05, 0.10, 0.15) present coupled steady plateaus. The voltage platform in the charging and discharging profiles do not vanish even though at 50 C, illustrating that the sodiation/desodiation processes are still in progress in MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped electrodes at high current densities. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a><span> exhibits the relationship between <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and doping amount in the materials. It can be seen that the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) displays the outstanding <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> of ∼358.2 Wh/kg (1 C), which is significantly higher than that of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0) (284.8 Wh/kg), the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (297.7 Wh/kg) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (269.4 Wh/kg).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Figs. 5 and S7 exhibit long cycling stability for the as-prepared NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) materials. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents an outstanding initial capacity of 103&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 C and exhibits the retention rate of 81.6% after 500 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). Even after 1000 cycles, the average coulombic efficiency is almost close to 100%. However, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.05) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>b) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.15) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>c) present the inferior capacities of 75.9 and 78.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> under the same condition. Furthermore, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) cathode can still deliver the initial capacity of 90.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 30 C and remain at 50.7&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 2000 cycles, indicating splendid long cycling performance. Nevertheless, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>a) electrode gives the initial specific capacity of 85&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 5 C, and only holds the capacity of 66.5&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles. In addition, the microstructures of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) after 500 cycles at 1 C are observed by SEM (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>). Compared with the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0), the morphology of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) changes little even after 500 cycles. The comparison of half-cell performance between this work and the recently reported investigations for sodium-ion batteries is shown in Table S4. Obviously, the overall electrochemical performance of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>(0.10), especially rate capability, is excellent among various NVP-based materials. Consequently, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) may be the promising <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> for SIBs because of its outstanding rate performance and long cyclic stability.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5.jpg" height="356" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (338KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (338KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Long cycling performance of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at the rates of 20 C (a) and 30 C (b), respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> displays the CV profiles of the NVP and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> between 2.4 and 4.3&nbsp;V. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>, the redox reactions of the NVP and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) occur at the voltage of&nbsp;∼3.4&nbsp;V, which is consistent with the extraction/insertion of Na<sup>+</sup><span> in the crystal structure of the NVP. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation process</a> is ascribed to the two-phase transition process of Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and NaV<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) displays a stronger oxidation peak than the NVP. As for the process of reduction, the peaks are divided into two parts due to the structural rearrangement when Na<sup>+</sup> transfers from the Na1 site to the Na2 site <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. The small reduction peak corresponds to the short discharge platform in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a. Moreover, the polarization voltage of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode between cathode and anode peaks is 211&nbsp;mV, which is visibly less than that of the NVP (301&nbsp;mV). Clearly, compared with the pristine NVP, MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP possesses excellent electrochemical reversibility and improved reaction kinetics.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>In order to further study the <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-kinetics-characteristics" title="Learn more about kinetic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kinetic properties</a> of the materials, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) tests are carried out. Nyquist diagram and the fitting result of EIS circuit model are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>a. The EIS spectra is composed of a semicircle and a slash in the high/low frequency regions. The semicircle is assigned to the charge transfer process, while the diagonal line is associated with the diffusion of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> (Warburg impedance) </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. Based on the calculation and fitting of equivalent circuit, the R<sub>ct</sub> of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) (252.2&nbsp;Ω) is much smaller than that of the NVP (408.3&nbsp;Ω), illustrating a faster charge transfer dynamic for the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b demonstrates the linear relationship of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) and the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) materials in the Ź vs ω<sup>−1/2</sup>. As calculated, the slope of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) is higher than that of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10), indicating a lower value of <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> (<em>D<sub>Na</sub></em>). Obviously, the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode presents low charge transfer resistance and fast Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics, indicating that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping can enhance rate capability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" height="230" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (174KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (174KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) EIS of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) with an equivalent circuit. (b) Relation between Ź and ω<sup>−1/2</sup> at low frequency of NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (x) (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0 and 0.10).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a><span> exhibits the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10). The shapes of the CV profiles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>a) at different rates (0.2–1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) are similar, and the peak current (<em>i</em>) increases with the increase of scanning rates (<em>v</em>), manifesting that there is a distinct capacitive behavior in the electrochemical process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. According to Eqs. (3) and (4) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>, the <em>b</em> values of oxidation and reduction peaks in CV profiles are 0.62 and 0.85, respectively, demonstrating that the dynamic behavior of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is controlled via both diffusion and capacitive behavior. The contribution rates of two controlled processes are obtained via formula (5) in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a>. The capacitive contribution is 94.14% at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>b). The proportions of capacitive/diffusion contribution at various scanning rates are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>c. When the scanning rates are 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, the contributions of capacitive behavior are 88.62, 93.37, 94.57, 94.91 and 95.37%, respectively, meaning that the outstanding rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) is mainly contributed via high capacitive behaviour <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a><span><span>. Galvanostatic intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) are used to further probe the </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/dynamic-characteristics" title="Learn more about dynamic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dynamic properties</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) and the corresponding results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>d-10f. It can be seen that the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> is mainly at the range of 10</span><sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>. There is no doubt that MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> doping facilitates the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup><span>, and the <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> modified NVP is higher than that of previously reported NASICON-type NVP materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The electrical effects of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> doped NVP are ascertained via the calculation of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (DOS) and the results are shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>. The crystal structures of the NVP and MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>-doped NVP is simulated, as displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b, the band gap of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0) is 4.97&nbsp;eV. For the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub><span> (0.10) (band gap&nbsp;=&nbsp;3.67&nbsp;eV), some new energy states appear around the bottom of <a href="/topics/chemistry/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a>, significantly narrowing the width of foregoing band gap in the pristine NVP and enhancing the electronic conductivity. Further analyzing the partial DOS (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0030" name="bs0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>) shows that these nascent states in the band gap above the E<sub>f</sub><span> mainly come from the contribution of <a href="/topics/chemistry/molybdenum-atom" title="Learn more about Mo atom from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Mo atom</a>. Hence, one can conclude that MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> doping could induce the change of local structure and modify the electronic structure. Thus, the appearance of new energy states may improve the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of the NVP </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7.jpg" height="491" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (558KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (558KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span>Structural diagram (a) and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (b) of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0) and NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">For illustrating the structural evolution of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode during desodiation/sodiation process, in-situ XRD of the material is collected. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 8</span></span></a><span> and S12 exhibit the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about diffraction patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffraction patterns</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) at different charge states. To be specific, the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;4), (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;4), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;6) and (3&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) four profiles shift to right. At discharging, the four peaks completely return to the initial state. Moreover, the (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;3) and (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;<span>1) peaks split into new peaks and gradually disappear. During discharging, the peaks gradually appear again. The results present that all the diffraction peaks significant change and gradually return to the pristine state during charging and discharging, indicating that the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> of the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) is highly reversible.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8.jpg" height="261" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (548KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (548KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. <span>In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) electrode during the first cycle.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">To summarize, we have synthetized Na<sub>(3+2x)</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>(3-x)</sub>MoO<sub>4(x)</sub> cathode materials as advanced cathodes for SIBs. The doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><span> significantly reduces the internal resistance and accelerates the migration rate of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> in the NVP-based materials, resulting in an obvious enhancement of electrochemical performance. The optimum content of MoO</span><sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> is 0.10. The NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) presents excellent rate capability and cycling stability, which exhibits the outstanding rate capability of 84.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup><span> at a superhigh <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 50 C. Moreover, the NVP-MoO</span><sub>4</sub> (0.10) shows a relatively specific capacity of 73.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with an average coulombic efficiency of 99.2% even at 20 C after 1000 cycles. The EIS measurement and DOS computation demonstrate that the faster sodium ion kinetics and lower band gap after the doping of MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> account for the excellent rate capability of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10). In-situ XRD manifests that the structure of the NVP-MoO<sub>4</sub> (0.10) undergoes a highly reversible phase transition process. We believe that the anionic doping strategy not only sheds a new insight for the modification of NVP, but also provides a reference for the practical application of polyanionic SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><strong>Xiao Liu:</strong> Investigation, Methodology, Conceptualization, Writing – original draft, Software. <strong>Juan Gong:</strong> Software, Visualization, Formal analysis. <strong>Xijun Wei:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Ling Ni:</strong> Data curation, Visualization. <strong>Houyang Chen:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Qiaoji Zheng:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Chenggang Xu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Dunmin Lin:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">This work was supported by Sichuan Science and Technology Program (2018JY0447) and Project of Southwest University of Science and Technology (No. 20zx7142).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Supplementary material</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The following are the Supplementary data to this article:<span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="m0005"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979721016738-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" title="Download Word document (3MB)"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" width="20" class="icon icon-text-document"><path d="M1 10v108h57.22L91 85.09V10H1m80 70.96L54.07 108H11V20h70v60.96zM43 100h10V80h20V70H43v30M25 32h42v10H25V32zm0 18h42v10H25V50z"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download Word document (3MB)</span></span></span></a></span><span class="captions text-s"><span><p><span class="label">Supplementary data 1</span>. </p></span></span></span></span></div></section></div></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="bi005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" id="ref-id-b0005" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0005"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">G. Xu, J. Chen, L. Tao, Z. Tian, S. Zhou, N. Zhao, C.-P. Wong</div><div id="ref-id-h0015" class="title text-m">Investigation of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>F as a sodium ion battery cathode material: Influences of morphology and voltage window</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Nano Energy, 60 (2019), pp. 510-519</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor pdf link anchor-primary Zhang, Y. Liu, X. Zhao, L. He, H. Liu, Y. Song, S. Sun, Q. Li, X. Xing, J. Chen</div><div id="ref-id-h0255" class="title text-m">A novel NASICON-type Na<sub>4</sub>MnCr(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> demonstrating the energy density record of phosphate cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Mater., 32 (11) (2020), p. 1906348, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.v32.1110.1002/adma.201906348" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1002/adma.v32.1110.1002/adma.201906348</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85079446867&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20novel%20NASICON-type%20Na4MnCr3%20demonstrating%20the%20energy%20density%20record%20of%20phosphate%20cathodes%20for%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2020&amp;author=J.%20Zhang&amp;author=Y.%20Liu&amp;author=X.%20Zhao&amp;author=L.%20He&amp;author=H.%20Liu&amp;author=Y.%20Song&amp;author=S.%20Sun&amp;author=Q.%20Li&amp;author=X.%20Xing&amp;author=J.%20Chen" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (32)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723017502"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A high-energy-density NASICON-type Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;1.25&lt;/inf&gt;Ga&lt;inf&gt;0.75&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode with reversible V&lt;sup&gt;4+&lt;/sup&gt;/V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt; redox couple for sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">The stable three-dimensional framework and high operating voltage of sodium superionic conductor (NASICON)-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> has the potential to work with long cycle life and high-rate performance; however, it suffers from the poor intrinsic electronic conductivity and low energy density. Herein, Ga<sup>3+</sup> is introduced into Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> to activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple at a high potential of 4.0&nbsp;V for enhancing energy density of the materials (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>). After the partial substitution of Ga<sup>3+</sup> for V<sup>3+</sup>, three redox couples (V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) of V are reversibly converted in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, suggesting multi-electrons (&gt;2e<sup>−</sup>) involved in the reversible reaction, and simultaneously the electronic conductivity of the materials is effectively enhanced. As a result, the cathode with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.75 exhibits excellent electrochemical properties: in the voltage range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, delivering an initial capacity of 105 mAh/g at 1C with a capacity retention rate of 92.3% after 400 cycles, and providing a stable reversible capacity of 88.3 mAh/g at 40C; and in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, presenting the reversible capacity 152.3 mAh/g at 1C (497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>), and cycling stably for 1000 cycles at 20C with a capacity decay of 0.02375% per cycle. It is found that the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes possess the sodium storage mechanism of single-phase and bi-phase reactions. This investigation presents a useful strategy to enhance the energy density and cycling life of NASICON-structured polyanionic phosphates by activating high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1005030223004383"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Cr-doped Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;@C enables high-capacity with V&lt;sup&gt;2+&lt;/sup&gt;/V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt; reaction and stable sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Materials Science and Technology</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The NVCP@C delivers an ultrahigh discharge capacity (175 mAh g–1) and cyclability (86% capacity retention for 2000 cycles). Compared with the recently reported NASICON-type SIB electrode materials [15,18,23,30,32,36,42,45,46], this work demonstrates good capacity, cycle performance, and rate performance (Table S3). In-situ XRD results demonstrate that there are two reversible sodium storage mechanisms during charge and discharge: two-phase reactions and solid solution reactions.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Due to its abundant sodium content and low cost, sodium-ion battery (SIB) has become an effective substitute and supplement for lithium-ion batteries, which has a broad development prospect in large-scale energy storage systems. Na-super-ionic conductor (NASICON) structural materials have stable 3D skeleton structures and open Na<sup>+</sup> transport channels, which is a very promising SIB cathode material. But in the typical NASICON material Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP), the number of electrons involved in NVP per formula unit is less than 2 at the stable voltage window, which limits the further improvement of battery performance. In this work, we report another NASICON structured Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>4/3</sub>Cr<sub>2/3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@C (NVCP@C), which is obtained by Cr-doped NVP through spray drying. By taking full advantage of the voltage platforms of V<sup>5+/4+</sup>, V<sup>4+/3+</sup>, and V<sup>3+/2+</sup> in the window of 1.5–4.4&nbsp;V, NVCP@C delivered a high discharge capacity (175 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>) and durable cyclability (86% capacity retention for 2000 cycles). <em>In-situ</em> X-ray diffraction results demonstrate that the reversible structural evolution accompanies by solid-solution reaction and two-phase reaction mechanisms co-exist during charge/discharge processes. When coupled with Na<sup>+</sup> pre-embedded hard carbon (HC), the assembled NVCP@C//HC full cell delivers a high capacity (105 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>) and long cycling performance (70% after 1000 cycles). This Cr-doped NVP method offers new insights into the design of high-energy NASICON-structured cathode materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2589234723000714"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Strategies and practical approaches for stable and high energy density sodium-ion battery: a step closer to commercialization</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Materials Today Sustainability</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are reckoned as a potential alternative to Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Currently, the limited supply of precursors and the cost of LIBs have regenerated research and development interest in SIBs. Due to differences in the chemistry of lithium (Li) and sodium (Na), optimized methods for LIBs cannot be blindly applied to develop SIBs. Along with the judicial selection of electrode materials, electrolytes, and interfaces are very crucial for safe, high-power, and long-lasting batteries. The initial part of this review deals with the challenges faced in commercializing SIB full cells. Subsequently, the strategies to improve the energy density of SIB full cells through electrode modifications and electrolyte engineering are described in detail. This review comprehensively represents notable insights into the large-scale commercialization of potential sodium-ion batteries in the full cell.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0022459622007940"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">The recent advances of NASICON-Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Solid State Chemistry</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Table 5 summary of NVPF cathodes with different modification methods in recent years. The substitution of anionic functional groups [141–143] is also a hot topic of current research. The common anionic functional groups include: MoO42− [141], SiO42− [144], etc.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">NASICON (super ionic conductor)-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) has been widely studied as a very promising cathode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical specific capacity, high voltage platform, good chemical stability, its unique three-dimensional (3D) open crystal structure, and the de/intercalation of sodium ions during charge/discharge. However, the high Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion ability of NVP is accompanied by the large bulk structure and poor electronic conductivity, which leads to poor electrochemical performance in terms of rate capability and cycling stability and thus impedes its practical application. Herein, the research development of NVP sodium ion cathode materials are reviewed in recent years. Based on the crystal structure and ion migration mechanism of NVP materials, the sodium storage mechanism and theoretical capacitance of NVP materials are introduced, and the effects of different preparation methods on the electrochemical properties of NVP materials are summarized and compared. The modification research strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of NVP electrode materials are mainly discussed, including carbon material modification, ion doping, and material Nano-crystallization. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and prospects for the future development of NVP cathodes.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/smll.202304002" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">High-Energy-Density Cathode Achieved via the Activation of a Three-Electron Reaction in Sodium Manganese Vanadium Phosphate for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2023, Small</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.nanolett.2c03916" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Bimetal Substitution Enabled Energetic Polyanion Cathode for stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 0h2.63v.934h-1.657v.894H16.6V6.4h-1.56v2.026h-.97V3.638"></path><path d="M19.462 13.46c.348 4.274-6.59 16.72-8.508 15.792-1.82-.85 1.53-3.317 2.92-4.366-2.864.894-5.394 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-none"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article3-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775321010430" title="Constructing hierarchical porous Fe/F-codoped Na3V2(PO4)3/C composite enwrapped with carbon nanotubes as high-performance cathode for symmetric sodium ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Constructing hierarchical porous Fe/F-codoped Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite enwrapped with carbon nanotubes as high-performance cathode for symmetric sodium ion batteries</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Power Sources, Volume 513, 2021, Article 230545</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Yanjun</span> <span>Chen</span>, …, <span>Li</span> <span>Guo</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775321010430/pdfft?md5=2491842b7314f481cdf42a7c96281b8e&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0378775321010430-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article3-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6
